replies.bodyText:
This method is for rewrite the ChunkGroup which is in the same time partition. In this case, we don't need to decode the Chunk data to points, just upgrade the headers of chunks and pages and then write to file. That's why I named it quickRewrite.
I prefer to add javadoc to explain this.
replies.author: HTHou

timeline.bodyText: add javadoc or rename to rewriteUnCompressedPage
timeline.author: qiaojialin

replies.bodyText: The same reason as above. This method is for rewriting the ChunkGroup which data is in the different time partitions. To rewrite this, we have to decode the data to points, and rewrite the data point to different chunkWriters.

+

+  }

+   * @throws WriteProcessException 
+   */
+  public static void upgradeOneTsfile(String tsFileName, List<TsFileResource> upgradedResources)

+    try (TsfileOnlineUpgradeTool updater = new TsfileOnlineUpgradeTool(tsFileName)) {
+      updater.upgradeFile(upgradedResources);

timeline.author: jt2594838

timeline.bodyText:
This is my understanding:
Files that are already in the partitioned folders (like data/sg1/0/1-1-1.tsfile) will not be upgraded, but files that are not in the partitioned folders  (like data/sg1/1-1-1.tsfile) will be moved to an upgrading folder (like data/sg1/upgrade/1-1-1.tsfile), upgraded and reloaded into IoTDB.
But what if the files in the partitioned folders also need upgrading?
timeline.author: jt2594838

replies.bodyText: This upgrade is only for 0.9.x -> 0.10.x, if they are in partitioned folder, they should already  be the 0.10.x version, because we do not have partition folder in 0.9.x
replies.author: qiaojialin

replies.bodyText: Then you should make sure that later versions of 0.10 will never change the file structure, or it will be painful.
replies.author: jt2594838
